job_title: Inside Sales Representative in San Antonio, TX
pros:
-Job Security: Throughout the pandemic, they didn't lay any of my co workers off.

-Pay is pretty decent if you're a college grad with no family or dependents.

-Regular work schedule M-F from 8-5, 7-4, or 9-6 depending on what 
time zone your business portfolio is in. 1hr lunch, and two 15 minute breaks
cons:
-Management: depending on your team lead and supervisor, it could be a very stressful time. Micromanaging is a hobby here. 

-No growth unless you're willing to relocate to Georgia for corporate position or become an Account Executive(outside sales) in a different state. No other opportunities at the job site. 

- Hitting NUMBERS always come first, no matter what. If you're sick, not feeling well even with a doctor's note, they do not care. You're still expected to bring in money.

- They change things all the time and wonder why things don't work out for them. 

- You're going to be thrown in the deep end. They train you about the shipping levels they want you to sell which isn't hard but If a customer is shipping special commodities, hazmat or any international documents outside of the commercial invoices, you're screwed because you won't receive any help. 

-Your business portfolio can change to different customers and the ones you had working on to bring in money will vanish. You will not get any credit for it. 

-If management gets beat up, it flows down to your you and your co workers. Some are given ultimatums. 

-Love to trash talk but call it "being competitive"

-They don't fire people. Instead they harass you until you are at your wits ends because they don't want to pay the unemployment payout. *Per Z's words (the Manager of SMB who "fires" people)

- Doing 3 jobs for 1 salary: Sales person, Technology/Integration Specialist, Customer Service/Claims Rep. 

*They all have departments that do these things but because of the Net Promoter Scores, our team leads are pressured which transfers to the reps on why we didn't talk about claims with the customer just to later get yelled out for not selling or hitting numbers.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Hodgkins, IL
pros:
Decent Pay with some opportunities to work overtime

Close Knit Group of People to work with - (This can also be a con if you don't exactly like the people in your area)

Repetitive and mindless work (can be a con too)

Opportunities to move up 
I dont know if this was because my managers were just trying to move up but I was offered chances to move up to management straight up after a month or two. But it really isn't worth the amount of work you take on with it for most. Especially if you don't have a car.
cons:
Repetitive and mindless work (can be a pro too)

Management will ask you to work faster regardless of how fast you are sometimes

Barely enough people to get help when needed

Some Trailers will have a higher package per minute coming to them than others, and sometimes you'll have to do what you can without help until someone comes at the last second as if you weren't struggling to keep up for the past hour. Management that I had would only send help once boxes were flooding all over the floor.

If you don't have a car, get ready to take a long bus ride everyday up to 2-3 and even 4 hours of commute a day. So get ready to be in a bus that can be so packed that you have to stand the entire way home after a long day of work. Almost every time.

This is a job which demands the best energy you have in the day, in exchange for a reliable paycheck.

pros:
Benefits

Gives you logistics experience

cons: I am proud to work for UPS as a company. The company itself does a lot of good, and takes care of its employees. When becoming a supervisor, you are no longer in the union, so you aren’t protected. As far as upper management is concerned, at least with my hub and my experience, it is toxic and degrading. My first months as a supervisor were hell, and I was miserable. I was set up to fail, and never received the proper or adequate training to actually succeed. Basically, I got in trouble for things I was never taught. The hub itself also isn’t safe. Seems like they only care about safety and sticking to the rules when corporate shows up. The hours can really hurt you too. While you make a decent hourly wage, if it isn’t peak season, you’ll struggle to even work 27+ hours.

pros: good pay, nice people and quick hire process
cons: Started my first day as a package handler today. Walk in and the manager didn't seem enthusiastic about us new hires. He was very quick with explaining things and didn't like questions. He gave us a 30 min tour of the building as then we where put with our supervisor. They put me and one of the other new hires in a large box truck. It was 70 degrees outside and felt like 100 inside the truck. They give you a brief explanation of how things work and then put you to work. After being in the truck for about 20 mins I was dripping and soaked in sweat. If you try to take a 20 sec break just to catch your breath, your supervisor barks at you to keep it moving. Im in relatively good physical shape at 20yrs old. After doing 4 trucks we got a 10 min break that was enough time to quickly refill my water bottle and use the bathroom. I got to sit for 3 min. That was just the beginning of the hell. After my break we started. to unload the UPS delivery vans. My first van had the whole floor and shelfs full of 50 lbs packages stacked 3 feet high. There is this unloading machine that is very dangerous to use. It's heavy and when you try to position it in the truck you can slip and fall from it being hard to use. I felt like I was going to have a heart attack lifting all those packages off the floor one after another. I only worked a 2.5 hour shift and I barely made it

review_title: Toxic Management and Hard Labor, but Incredible Benefits
pros:
If you're desperate for work or you need health insurance for yourself and your family, UPS might be a good option for you.

The pay is barely adequate, but overtime is guaranteed during the holidays and usually available all year.

Above all else, the health insurance plan is the best you can get, bar none. All benefits are available to part time employees and their families. Some highlights include: no premiums, minimal copays, routine checkups, vision, dental, mental health, excellent medication coverage, and more.
cons:
Absolutely horrendous culture, management, and working conditions on top of a job that would be back-breaking no matter what.

Expect to be yelled at daily for failing to meet impossible performance goals, while management actively makes your job harder. 

By the time you've been there a year, you'll be one of the most senior employees, including the supervisors who tell you how to do your job.

Management is explicitly trained to use manipulation and bullying to communicate with and "motivate" employees. Rather than focus on realistic improvements to efficiency and job flow, management actively creates problems and scrambles to clean them up. The start time is different every day to minimize man hours, despite the entire building being understaffed and overworked.

Dress as though you were working outdoors, because the main warehouse is barely heated and has no AC. Water and bathrooms are a 5 minute walk, and the entire facility is absolutely filthy. You will ruin any clothes you wear in there.

Finally, you'll be dealing with all of this while doing a job that would be back breaking and exhausting in the best of circumstances. You'll walk miles and move thousands of pounds of packages every day. During peak season (Thanksgiving - Valentine's Day), mandatory 60 hour weeks are the norm.

70% of new hires quit within 30 days, and most that make it a month don't last a year.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Atlanta, GA
pros: Hours are consistent, if you want to stay late you can. Benefits are good. MIGHT make for a good high school gig
cons: Due to COVID, we’ve been hit with effectively near peak-season flow year round. To compete with FedEx and Amazon, they raised starting pay company wide to $17.50 until at least 2022. They did not raise supervisors pay, and as a result many left since they were barely being paid more than the handlers (supervisors are ~$19/hr). I’m a belt tender (same pay as package handler) and they haven’t been able to staff me with a supervisor for about 6 months now. As a result I basically have had no choice but to fill both positions for no extra benefits or pay. On a side note I’m probably going to refuse to continue that state of affairs much longer. The Union is ok at best, starter pay for the company has NOT kept up with inflation over the past 30 years even if you factor in the huge raise we got in May ($14.50 to $17.50 for the rest of the year) which will probably go away or be reduced, depending on if management is willing to accept the exodus that will occur as a result. My experience with management has been all negative, multiple times they’ve asked for PT supervisor applicants, I’ve applied and they haven’t even dignified my applications with a “thanks but no thanks,” they just don’t give me a response at all. I would not recommend this job to anyone at this time

review_title: One of the best retirement plans of public companies
job_title: Planning Services Senior Analyst in Alpharetta, GA
pros:
There's a 3% 401k match and 5% of your salary contribution to your 401k starting out. The salary contribution eventually goes to 8%. Eventually the company is putting 11% in your 401k. This in my opinion makes UPS one of the top places to work if you are worried about having enough to retire. Also the bonus structure for supervisors and above gives you a stake in the company plus cash. These two combined over the long term can lead to a large wealth generation. :)

Finally the people rock.
cons: Very traditional company though this seems to be changing. Peak can be extremely stressful depending on the department.

pros: The only decent thing about this job is the pay, and the bonus you’re suppose to get for good attendance which you probably won’t see until it’s almost over.
cons: They are very VERY sexist, I am a strong 25 year old female and they gave me a decent role I can keep up with. I was very excited to start my first day, I was the preload shift. My first and LAST day was absolutely a nightmare! I arrived 10 minutes early and when I got to where I needed to go by finding it myself they just stared at me didn’t say a word. They ended up having a meeting across from me and didn’t include me or say a word. Once I spoke up they all departed and ignored me. Finally a big boss came over and ordered someone to put me somewhere. Once I got to my station I was not trained at all and I asked the lady before she could run off if I could grab my inhaler because I have asthma. She responded “I have crazy asthma and you have the easiest job you’ll be fine” and walked off. The guy next to me helped me and he had only been there a week! So a few hours in my asthma starts acting up intensely and I find someone to ask if I can grab it and they said yes but quickly. As I’m going back to my car I got yelled at for leaving my station. I went to my car and NEVER returned. Absolutely the worst job I’ve ever been to. I’m not sure if it’s because I’m a girly female or what but I am very strong just short and they definitely judged a book by it’s cover. I was doing boxes faster than men 2x my size. 0 out of 10 do not recommend.

job_title: Plant Engineering Supervisor in New York, NY
pros: Company is established and has been an industry leader for a century. Work is plentiful. Company offers internal transfers to other departments and locations. Pay can be rewarding once you obtain a non operational role within the company. Company promotes from within. Work can feel rewarding at times.
cons: Company culture can be very challenging as change comes very slow. Promote from within overlooks outside talent for higher positions. Tendency to rely solely on people who have been with the company a long time and not merit. Days and weeks can be long as you could easily work 12-16 hour per day, 6-7 days a week in a salaried position. Expectation to answer calls and texts almost 24/7, even on days off and vacations for certain positions/roles. Pay can feel meager once hours worked per week is calculated. Benefits are inferior to union hourly employees. Culture of yelling, swearing and badgering to get it done by any means necessary, even cheating is rampant. Employee turnover for talented and driven employees continues to plague this organization in all ranks and positions as burnout is high.

review_title: They do not value my time in the slightest
pros: If you like being on your feet most the day, it's a great job. Working outside is great when the weather is nice. High level of independence.
cons:
After the day they said "you’re hired" it took 6 weeks before I was able to start training because "they didn't have enough training staff." I did zoom training for 1 week, then I couldn't start road training for another 2 weeks because of the same reason. Once I actually started, at least once a week (many times twice) I would get called off because there wasn't enough work. Not the biggest deal if they told me in advance. But they wouldn't tell me half the time. I would wake up early, make my lunch, drive 30 min to work, only to find out it's time to drive 30 min home because there's no work for me. As a full time employee, I am expected to be at work, on time, unless otherwise told. But management can't take 2 min out of their day to tell me i'm not working. It's disrespectful to me and clear they do not value my time. I told them how much it bothered me. They are wasting my whole morning and I get paid nothing for it. But nothing changed. They keep doing it. 
Please remember, life isn't all about money. Ask any old person, "what is the one thing you wish to has more of?" Not a single one will say money. TIME. Time is your most valuable resource in this short life on earth. When a company does not value your time, they do not value you. When business takes a downturn because Amazon has built a delivery service with modern technology and continuously innovates, who's getting cut first? Think about that before you buy into their "you are in a privileged position to work for the great UPS, this will be your life long career" rhetoric.
